heading.title: PART 8 ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS AND ORDERS [ss 102–138]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 8 ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS AND ORDERS [ss 102–138]
[s 117] s 117 Operation of garnishee order in relation to debts (cf Act No 9 1973, section 97)

leg:heading.title: Operation of garnishee order in relation to debts (cf Act No 9 1973, section 97)

p.text: Subject to the uniform rules, a garnishee order operates to attach, to the extent of the amount outstanding under the judgment, all debts that are due or accruing from the garnishee to the judgment debtor at the time of service of the order.
For the purposes of this Division, any amount standing to the credit of the judgment debtor in a financial institution is taken to be a debt owed to the judgment debtor by that institution.

An assignee of the whole of the judgment debt is entitled to issue execution (Goodman v Robinson (1887) 18 QBD 332; Bagley v Bleume; Ex parte Lee (1890) 16 VLR 8 but not the assignee of part only: Forster v Baker [1910] 2 KB 636; [1908–10] All ER Rep 554 ; Re Steel Wing Co Ltd [1921] 1 Ch 349; [1920] All ER 292 . If a judgment creditor has obtained an order for payment of a judgment debt by instalments they may only commence proceedings in respect of the instalments for which the debtor is in default: Woodham Smith v Edwards [1908] 2 KB 899 .

It is essential that the alleged debt arises from a subsisting debtor and creditor relationship between the judgment debtor and the garnishee: Howell v Metropolitan Railway Co (1881) 19 Ch D 508 . Money alleged to be due as a result of a claim on an insurance policy does not constitute an attachable debt: Israelson v Dawson [1933] 1 KB 301 . A mere verdict for damages is not a debt: Synnot v Woods (1891) 4 WN (NSW) 4; Jones v Thompson (1858) 27 LJQB 234 but a judgment is: Holtby v Hodgson (1889) 24 QBD 103 . Similarly an unquantified entitlement under an order for costs cannot be the subject of a garnishee order: Widgery v Tepper (1877) 6 Ch D 364 . Money paid to an officer of the court is not properly the subject of an order (Vernon v Perry [1962] VR 223 ; Cummings v Cooke (1867) 7 SCR (NSW) L 17) nor are dividends held by the Official Receiver and payable in the administration of the bankrupt estate (Prout v Gregory (1890) 24 QBD 281), unless the deceased was actually indebted to the garnishee at the time of his death: Stevens v Phelips (1875) LR 10 Ch App 417. No garnishee order can be made in respect of fees “due” to counsel — unless the barrister has an enforceable entitlement to recover them: Wells v Wells [1914] P 157 . A trustee is not a debtor to his cestuis que trust until he holds money which he ought to pay over, or until he has by some default made himself personally liable: Webb v Stenton (1883) 11 QBD 518 ; cf Re Greenwood [1901] 1 Ch 887 . Moneys representing the net balance of an estate in the hands of an administrator or executor pending final distribution cannot be attached: Mendell v Wason (1897) 23 VLR 176 ; O’Neil v Gilbert (1884) 1 WN (NSW) 7; Vernon v Perry [1962] VR 223 . However, proceeds of execution in the hands of the sheriff may be attached: Thompson & Co v Vrenderberg (1888) 14 VLR 150 . Where the judgment debtor cannot assign the right to receive payment, for example, in the case of a maintenance order or a pension, the right to payment is not subject to garnishee proceedings: Re Robinson (1884) 27 Ch D 160 ; Watkins v Watkins [1896] P 222 ; Birch v Birch (1883) 8 PD 163 ; Lucas v Harris (1887) 18 QBD 127. Where a debt is attached to satisfy a local judgment before a foreign bankruptcy intervenes, the attachment is valid and prevails over the foreign bankruptcy since the rules of relation-back do not apply in the local forum: Galbraith v Grimshaw [1910] AC 508 at 510, 512, 513; [1908–10] All ER Rep 561 ; Union Bank v Tuttle (1889) 15 VLR 258 , applied in ML Ubase Holdings Co Ltd v Trigem Computer Inc [2007] NSWSC 859; BC200706318 .
Legislation cited in [s 117.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

The fact that the amount of the debt has not been precisely ascertained does not prevent a garnishee order being made: De Pass v Capital & Industries Corp [1891] 1 QB 216 ; O’Driscoll v Manchester Insurance Committee [1915] 3 KB 499 . The expression “due or accruing” includes: (i) debts that are immediately due and payable (see the preceding note); and (ii) accrued liabilities whose payment has been deferred. It does not include merely contingent liabilities where both the event that crystallises the liability, and the time for its due payment, rest in the future: Dunlop and Ranken Ltd v Hendall Steel Structures Ltd [1957] 3 All ER 344; [1957] 1 WLR 1102 ; Neustadt v Sammon (1915) 32 WN (NSW) 32 ; Breen v Doyle (1920) 37 WN (NSW) 258 . Consistently with that distinction a garnishee order can be made for payment to the judgment creditor as and when the debts fall due. This has particular application in the case of debts which are payable by installments as such an order avoids the necessity of making a fresh order in respect of each installment: Tapp v Jones (1875) LR 10 QB 593; Re Cowans Estate (1880) 14 Ch D 638 . But money paid into a bank account after service of the order is not bound by a garnishee order: Heppenstall v Jackson [1939] 1 KB 585; [1939] 2 All ER 10 ; Bank of New South Wales v Barlex Investments Pty Ltd [1964–5] NSWR 546; (1964) 81 WN (Pt 2) (NSW) 281 . Salary which is not due at the time of service of the garnishee order is not an accruing debt to which the order applies: Hall v Pritchett (1877) 3 QBD 215 ; Rand v Mann (1893) 9 WN (NSW) 121 ; cf Universal Guarantee Pty Ltd v Derefink [1958] VR 51 ; and see also District Court Act 1973 s 98 .

Where the judgment debtor and another person are jointly indebted to the garnishee the debt cannot be attached: Lloyd v Jacobs (1887) 3 WN (NSW) 144; Cramsie v Hunter (1888) 4 WN (NSW) 131; Phillips v McMahon (1899) 15 WN (NSW) 206 ; Hirschorn v Evans [1938] 2 KB 801; [1938] 3 All ER 491 . But if the liability is several or joint and several the position is otherwise: DJ Colburt & Sons Pty Ltd v Ansen [1966] 2 NSWR 289; (1966) 85 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 64 . If the judgment debt is itself a joint debt the judgment creditor may nevertheless attach debts due to any of the joint judgment debtors: Miller v Mynn (1859) 28 LJQB 324 .

CPA s 106(6) expressly provides for garnishee and charge orders to be made in relation to debts owed by the Crown. In the absence of such a provision there are authorities for the view that debts owing by the Crown and its instrumentalities cannot be the subject of attachment: Magann v Cooke (1884) 1 WN (NSW) 68; Cullen Bullen Lime Co v Roseby (1889) 5 WN (NSW) 52 (salary of a public servant may not be attached). However, the more accurate position may be that the Crown’s liability to garnishment depends on establishing the existence of an enforceable debt. Neither a garnishee nor a charge order can be made unless the hypothesised “creditor” has a right of action in relation to the amount claimed: R v Justices of Brisbane (1901) 11 QLJ 77 at 80 ; Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v Establissements Lecorche Freres [1954] QSR 314; Mildura Co-op Fruit Co Ltd v Noyce; Ex parte Minister of Agriculture [1928] VLR 390; (1928) 34 ALR 234 . The mere fact that a statutory authority represents the Crown would not prevent the issue of a garnishee order if the debt was otherwise actionable under the general law: WA Purvis Stores Pty Ltd v Richardson [1941] VLR 56 (road authority liable to attachment); Imperial Paint Manufacturers Pty Ltd v Harrison (1952) 72 WN (NSW) 127 (provision expressly subjecting a statutory authority to liability to “sue and be sued”). Conversely CPA s 106(6) would not enlarge the Crown’s liability as a garnishee if the amount in dispute was not in fact recoverable at the instance of the hypothesised crown creditor.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 118] s 118 Time within which payment to be made (cf Act No 9 1973, section 97B; Act No 11 1970, section 47B)

leg:heading.title: Time within which payment to be made (cf Act No 9 1973, section 97B; Act No 11 1970, section 47B)

p.text: Payment of an amount with respect to a debt attached by a garnishee order must be made:
within 14 days after the date on which the order is served on the garnishee, or
if the order attaches a debt that falls due after that date, within 14 days after the date on which the debt falls due.
